description: Borrowed from Middle French attester, from Latin attestor (“to witness to, bear witness”), from at-, combining form of ad (“to”) + testor (“to bear witness”), from testis (“a witness”).

verbs.description: attest (third-person singular simple present attests, present participle attesting, simple past and past participle attested)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To affirm to be correct, true, or genuine.
examples: When will the appraiser attest the date of the painting?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To certify by signature or oath.
examples: You must attest your will in order for it to be valid.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To certify in an official capacity.
(transitive, intransitive) To supply or be evidence of.
examples: Her fine work attested her ability.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To call to witness; to invoke.
